issues.title: Missing Merit System Requirements
issues.description: California Education Code requires school districts to establish a merit system for classified personnel including competitive selection procedures, probationary periods, and disciplinary procedures. The policy and regulation lack these fundamental merit system components.

legal_citations.text: The governing board of each school district shall establish a merit system of personnel administration for classified employees... The merit system shall include provisions for competitive selection, probationary periods, performance evaluation, disciplinary procedures, and appeals.

issues.required_language: The district shall establish and maintain a merit system for classified personnel that includes competitive selection procedures, probationary periods, performance evaluations, disciplinary procedures, and appeal processes in accordance with Education Code sections 45240-45320.

issues.title: Missing Physical Examination Requirements
issues.description: Education Code requires physical examinations for classified employees. While AR mentions this obligation exists for exempt employees, neither document establishes the requirement for regular classified employees.

legal_citations.text: No person shall be employed in a classified position in any school district unless he has been examined by a physician and surgeon... and found to be free from any contagious or infectious disease and physically and mentally competent to perform his duties.

issues.required_language: All classified employees shall undergo physical examination by a physician and surgeon and be found free from contagious or infectious disease and physically and mentally competent to perform assigned duties prior to employment.

issues.title: Missing Fingerprinting Requirements
issues.description: Education Code mandates fingerprinting for classified employees. While AR references this requirement for exempt employees, it's not established for regular classified personnel.

legal_citations.text: No person shall be employed in a classified position by any school district unless he has had his fingerprints taken and has been cleared by the Department of Justice.

issues.required_language: All classified employees shall submit fingerprints and receive clearance from the Department of Justice prior to employment as required by Education Code section 45125.

issues.title: Missing Tuberculosis Testing Requirements
issues.description: Education Code requires tuberculosis testing for school employees. While AR mentions this for exempt employees, the requirement is not established for regular classified personnel.

legal_citations.text: Each person employed by a school district in a classified or certificated position shall have, prior to the commencement of service, an examination to determine that such person is free of active tuberculosis.

issues.required_language: All classified employees shall undergo tuberculosis examination and be found free of active tuberculosis prior to commencement of service as required by Education Code section 49406.

issues.title: Missing Probationary Period Specifications
issues.description: Education Code requires specific probationary periods for classified employees, but neither document establishes these requirements.

legal_citations.text: The probationary period for a classified employee shall be six months of actual service, except that the probationary period for a classified employee in a supervisory or management position shall be 12 months of actual service.

issues.required_language: Classified employees shall serve a probationary period of six months of actual service, except supervisory or management positions which require 12 months of actual service, during which time performance shall be evaluated and permanent status may be granted.

issues.title: Outdated Policy Date
issues.description: The policy was last updated in 2009 and may not reflect current legal requirements or best practices. Regular review is recommended to ensure ongoing compliance.

legal_citations.text: The governing board of a school district may initiate and carry on any program, activity, or may otherwise act in any manner which is not in conflict with or inconsistent with, or preempted by, any law and which is not in conflict with the purposes for which school districts are established.

issues.required_language: Regular review and updating of policies and regulations to ensure compliance with current law and best practices.
